review_title: Great benefits, job security, but the usual bureaucracy
job_title: Program Manager in Portland, OR
pros: Kaiser is a great place to work and build a career over time. In my experience salaries are above market for most positions, and the benefits are so good that many people become "lifers". The health coverage is extremely generous, and time off starts off adequate and gets better over time (18 days when you start, moving up to 33 after 15+ years - this does not include sick time). Employees truly believe in the mission of KP (at least, I do) and it's clear that this is a place where employees' contributions are valued. Although my role is not part of any of the unions, the fact that our workforce is predominantly unionized also places a positive role in KP's reputation as a good place for workers (although having unionized staff also presents many challenges). Overall, I enjoy working at KP and would recommend it to others, but understand that you are entering a big bureaucracy. A friendly, mission-driven bureaucracy, but still.
cons:
Cons: having lots of "lifers" means that innovative ideas and workflows are not always adopted without a fight. People have their roles deeply embedded here, and any threat to the status quo is seen as negative, even though we need to make some pretty radical changes given the new health care environment post-ACA.  There's a lot of "not my job" attitudes here. It's hard to navigate the layers of bureaucracy, both in terms of personnel/HR/benefits, and in getting work done (there are often 4-5 departments at the regional and national KP levels working on similar areas, and no guidance on who does what.)  Be aware that KP is not immune to reorganizations and layoffs -- they do make a good attempt to ensure workers are hired elsewhere in the organization, but there are no guarantees, and there can be a lot of turnover in certain departments.

Benefits are currently generous but are always subject to downgrades in the future, so just be aware of that. Some changes to the pension and retiree medical benefits are about to hit, and with them a wave of Baby Boomers will be taking retirement, which should hopefully open up many new management opportunities for Millennials. 

Oh, and the biggest con of all: we still - STILL - use Lotus Notes for email. Shocking, I know, but true.

job_title: Consultant II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits and PTO policy - up to 29 days a year after 9 years of employment, starting at 17 days until the end of Y1. 500 hours a year can roll over. Insurance is cheap - $50 bucks for a single person for the mid plan.
cons: Pay is substantially lower than other companies and industries for similar roles. Due to the new "spans and layers" initiative there is now a requirement for managers to oversee a minimum of 10-12 people, so if you're early in your career, you'll stay at the IC level since they don't know how to give people enough managerial experience to move into a role overseeing 12 people. The tuition reimbursement is paltry - $3,000/yr when most strategic business roles have "MBA preferred" attached to them (an MBA is roughly $150k from a school worth going to) Kaiser is a place where you go to collect a paycheck for your entire career, and for some that's ok, but if you're looking to advance in your career, not the place. Most execs are riding that pension train all the way to retirement and don't have growth mindsets.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Baldwin Park, CA
pros: Great salary and benefit, easy to navigate benefit from HR online
cons: Micro managed, overworked, feels that I was replaceable, underdog, and culturally backstabbing each other. I worked for Kaiser Permanente for 13 years. I was proud being a Kaiser Permanente employee before, and this was when I was in my late 20s to 30s. Kaiser was great then as I was a single woman, and starting to build my career. After three kids, and two Workers Comp's case for my work permanent injury, Kaiser was not so worth it anymore. Management blamed everything on me, as we all know we always under staffed and very difficult to find help to reposition patients. Colleagues and charge nurses would help, but they wouldn't like me so much afterwards. I often heard that colleagues would talked about other colleagues in a negative way. Not to make the situation worse, I was transferred to another department after my leave of absence, and the Department Administrator accused me of a lot of things that I did not do such as "missing for hours" while in fact I was sent to Flu Clinic by the Charge Nurse to help out. and what a good leader should do, was investigate and verify right? no, she went straight to write a corrective action and pushed me to sign it. Like what others had mentioned, the Union was a joke. I never asked for help other than when this happened, and they replied that I just came back from a leave and I needed to prove myself. Again, it just felt that I was nobody, I was just a robot doing whatever they asked the staff to do/ fill out, and that my critical thinking was not appreciated. Pretty much, just be quiet, do whatever the checklists were, and I would do just fine. I was in grad school as well, and the Department Admin said that this department was not suitable for me then. I was shocked as I thought as a great leader, we supposed to encourage and motivate our staff to reach higher in life. I reported it to HR for investigation, and..... nada. Again, I was nobody for them, and I was not an asset to them, plus with everyone wanted to work for Kaiser, they probably glad I was out their company. I finally resigned after 13 years considering my mental health and my family well being is more important than staying in Kaiser for a great pay and salary. By the way, I worked in other company as well during the same time I worked for Kaiser (and still do now), and I felt my professional nursing expertise was valued and appreciated. Of course, they pay much less, but being happy in the work environment, make a better quality of life.

job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in San Diego, CA
pros: San Diego Kaiser is not what it used to be. They took our bonuses and also the one passed down from the state of California, Kaiser has kept it. We were not even given that one that is supposed to be given by the state.
cons: San Diego Kaiser is severely underpaying the LVNs and Nurses with the false pretense of cost of living. You get paid $30-32 per hour. The fact is that San Diego has become one of the most expensive cities in the whole state of California. We are underpaid and undervalue. We are also not fully compensated for the expense of having to use our own vehicle to travel from one Kaiser clinic to another in the whole county of San Diego. California employers are responsible for paying 56 cents per mile as mileage reimbursement and guess what? Kaiser is not doing that. It is a lawsuit waiting to happen. Imagine getting paid 30-32 per hour and of top of that… extra expenses on gas to go to different locations when you applied to be in one clinic, but are forced into other locations. Kaiser wants to save so much money that it expects us to do the job of receptionist, the scheduler, the accountant, the cleaner, etc on top of all our nursing responsibilities we already have, make phone calls, restocked supplies, clean the rooms, do quality checks, do inventories. We have to do all these endless tasks, questionnaires in less than 10 minutes and room patients in 5 minutes, because there’s double booking appointments or patients booked every 10 minutes. How can we give the appropriate time and dedication to our patients when we are expected to be running like machines? The healthcare system is broken and Kaiser is part of the problem. It is exploitation at its finest and causing nurses to fall into emotional exhaustion and extreme burnout. Why is our government allowing this to happen?

cons: They don’t care about reps at all. You’re just another number. Don’t be fooled by the union. Union is created by the company and the union reps are just csr’s just like you under the same management. No one is on your side. There’s a policy in place to write you up for everything you do. Some managers are clueless and seems to be a case of someone knowing someone to get their position. The job all around is mentally abusive. There’s a system to tract everything you do. You may work west coast hours on Eastern time and there is absolutely no mercy on your personal life working these hours. You will be drained tied to headset until 9 at night with someone sitting in the background watching your phone status to make sure you are tied to your computer. Sometimes they sit on the phone while you are taking calls and listen to you. You will begin to take those corrective actions with no regret. You will find it’s much better than being monitored for 8.5 hours a day. As a rep, you are just the janitor for the company’s many mistakes. No other department takes the time to help members. First thing they do is tell them to call the call center. We are the only department in this company held accountable for members experience so all the pressure is on you. And honestly when it all boils down to the mental abuse of this job.. the pay is no longer worth it. When you are at your wits end mentally, you have been beat down and drained from the members and being micromanaged, there is nothing you can do. Suck it up, get on the phones or be threatened to be fired.

job_title: Patient Access Representative II in Clackamas, OR
pros: Incomparable Health Insurance plans that I cannot find elsewhere.
cons: Kaiser used to have a large, $10-$11 window of pay growth. You would start around $20/hr, and that could increase over time leading to $31/hr. Unfortunately, the beginning wages start around $24, and the ceiling is still about $31. The only raises the company has provided throughout the economic inflation has been the obligatory cost of living raises that other companies are obligated to provide as well. This place has what seems to be a myriad of certifications and obstacles required to even get an interview - they hold themselves in high regard. If and when you are able to get in, you feel like you accomplished something, and are about to work a very great company. That is how it felt when I was hired in 2017. Unfortunately, since the pandemic hit, this place has been riddled with questionable politics, and severe understaffing. We used to have 50+ employees running the operations. It was a smooth, good spirited, positive work culture, and patient reviews were - on average - pretty good. Ever since the mass firing of employees took place when people were forced to get a COVID vaccine, most of the positions fired were never replaced. They claim it was for budget purposes, but then ironically congratulated us on our hard work and bragged about record profits. We are barely functioning with a skeleton crew, legit not finishing our work half of the time, because there is literally not enough physical bodies to operate this place correctly. They have taken advantage of us by watching us work 4 different jobs, and never replacing those that left. We are now only 35 or less employees, barely making it happen. I come to work doing 5 times the amount of work I used to back in 2017, our patients are constantly upset and verbally abusing us because they call us lazy for "working slow" when trying to check everyone in for their appointments, but unfortunately, we are going as fast as we can. So fast that we are not even doing our job thoroughly, just so that we can bring down the waiting-line, and get people to their appointments on time. We used to have 5 people checking in an average volume of 400 people a day (for a 12 hour shift), to now an average 3 people working, checking in an average volume of 600 people a day. Kaiser is failing to recognize that the quality of our patient reviews and experiences have a direct relationship to how they staff their facilities. People are tired of working in these conditions. Call-outs are more frequent because people are emotionally, and physically drained and sick of working overtime. The only reason our department is keeping their head above water, is because overtime is offered, and people are picking up more than their core 40 hours a week. So, our department is working under delusion. It looks like it is barely functioning, but that is because the employees are working overtime as a normal work week now. The money is good when needed, but the quality of morale is atrocious. No one is happy, everyone is burned out and there is a massive deficit of positivity. It's really hard to work in these conditions, get denied bonuses due to "not making numbers" but being severely understaffed. Kaiser expects us to reach goals that were written for a 50+ employee department, with a 35-employee department. We feel severely underappreciated. The only reason people stay longer than they want to, is because they rely on the health insurance benefits, and Kaiser knows that, and is taking advantage of us. A McDonalds fast food restaurant 3 mins down the road has starting jobs at $20+/hr with zero requirements of certifications or any realistic responsibilities in comparison to our department. Their starting wages have almost grown by 60%. Our starting pay has increased only by 15%. If we had our starting wages proportionately grow at a similar rate that McDonalds has, we should be STARTING around $36, and then be able to still grow 50% in wages, like our original window or growth used to be. Things have changed for places like McDonalds, places that require nothing more than entry level skills, but nothing has changed for places like Kaiser, places that require a lot of skills and responsibility, and have been much more relevant and NEEDED during the pandemic - it's HEALTH CARE for crying out loud. Do I need to say more? Kaiser is falling apart.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor/Psychotherapist in Richmond, CA
pros: My coworkers were amazing, and I had some great managers too. Working with the community and supporting the patients was so rewarding!
cons: Kaiser is all about maximizing profit. and providing as little care as possible--the patients, especially communities of color, shoulder this burden on the receiving end, while doctors, providers, and clinicians are leaving in droves. Don't believe KP's PR campaign; they spend tons of money to maintain their image and to fight the unions (check out how they treated NUHW mental healthcare workers in California and Hawaii). Some managers are great, but most are burned out, overworked, and pass the stress and overwhelm onto their staff. What's hard is once you're in, it's hard to leave--the benefits are good and the pay is decent (doctors call it "golden handcuffs") but in the long-run, your ethics, values, and integrity will suffer. It's ironic that a healthcare provider cares so little about the health of their employees.

review_title: Great Pay in lieu of Free Time
job_title: Clinical Appeals RN in Pasadena, CA
pros: When taken benefits into account, Kaiser Permanente is probably one of the top three healthcare providers to work for in California. I was comfortably making around $140,000 a year when I left. My job was exempt and I did have weekends off
cons: Exempt jobs at Kaiser Permanente pay well. But you are always going to work well over 40 hours a week. It has become the culture there. If you need time off because of a dental appointment or doctors appointment your manager can make life very difficult by asking for a note . They will even ask you to work after your appointment. Over the past decade management has had fewer leaders with clinical experience which has had an affect on morale and work life balance. Current upper management is the MBA type in which the only thing that matters is the bottom line. Workers morale and workers rights are not even a consideration anymore. Which is very unfortunate because For a brief time in the early 2000s Kaiser Permanente could have taken a different tack and truly been the leader in quality healthcare and led the way in treating their employees well. But leadership Chose the easy pass of “well all the other companies are cutting back why can’t we“? And that mantra of bringing Kaiser back to the pack persists today. The old timers who have at least a decade in aren’t gonna leave because the retirement benefits are good. But folks with less than a decade would probably follow my lead and find a much more rewarding less stressful workplace for just a little bit less pay.

Have incompetent managers and fake managers.

job_title: Medical Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits hands down that I have ever seen.
cons:
The onboarding process is slow, all over the place and totally disorganized. They have acronyms for everything under the sun and they don't preface them with what they stand for. You are just supposed to know what they stand for and that's it. This includes initial training both online & in clinic.

The EHR they use (Epic) is also difficult to use if you are not familiar with it. There is little to no training (department specific) with Epic either. You learn as you go.

If you are a new graduate who has no experience with Epic, this is *NOT* the place for you to work. Training consists of someone clicking a bunch of times within the computer screen & saying, "Go here, here , there, & then here. But remember this will change from patient to patient. " No explanation of what *here* is called(for a reference point.)

Speed is all that matters in regards to everything from vital signs to procedures; accuracy not so much.(Vital signs are to be taken & entered in to the computer in 3 minutes period. 

Street 'em & treat 'em seems to be the policy at the clinic I worked in. No time to talk with patients & get to build a rapport with them.

Constant badmouthing of other partner clinics outside of the Kaiser network.

review_title: Not what it used to be
job_title: Consultant in Oakland, CA
pros: -Healthcare is not going anywhere. -For non-profit status, the pay is decent -Benefits are decent (if frontline was taken care of better, benefits would be that much better).
cons: -Managers are bosses, not leaders (very few true leaders in the organization) -Micromanagement Permanente might be a better name for the org -Managers can be bullies, can be narcissists, but will still be protected by HR if they know the right people -The org is very big on 'speak-up culture' until you actually speak up, then you may be put on a plan and threatened with termination. -Management -If you are not in a union and are in program offices or regional offices, good luck having any checks and balances with boss's behavior. -Bosses working from home may tend to their personal needs all day but will expect you to be at your desk 9-5 -Bosses may be incompetent and may be managing people who are smarter and more qualified than them. If boss has ego issue, they will let said employees feel their wrath. -If a boss has hookups, even after multiple complaints from employees and unions, they can still be given a bigger and better role, if they know the right people (we've seen this happen). -Toxic work culture and hostile work environments are common. HR will tell you to use EAP who just listen to you but can't do anything. - The list is endless to be honest...but consider this list null and void if you happen to be one of the lucky ones to get a good manager. Note: If you are not this type of boss, then don't worry, this doesn't apply to you. There are still plenty of overall great managers in the organization who understand people and are pleasant to work with, but unfortunately many still do not.

job_title: APPOINTMENT CLERK in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Pay is starting 23$ after a year now 26$. Benefits are not even good. Kaiser health scare is the worst. Maybe I’m biased bc I had PPO before and never have to do with these incompetent doctors
cons: Kaiser is filled with employees who all Hate their jobs bc the patient demographic ruins it. You deal with the nastiest people on earth who do not care. Call center is the worst job I’ve ever worked. They are extremely low staffed bc of how they operate!! Good luck trying to get any time off! Your requests will get denied everytime but somehow they off early leave days??? Makes no sense if requests are denied for staffing needs 100% of the time why are you offering early paid leave throughout the day!??? Kaiser should seriously just close down appoint system overall and move it to the individual offices where nursing staff handles it. I would not recommend this job to anyone. Your mental and physical health will disengrate. You wake up everyday hating your life and the job you chose. You have the option of working from home but please do not expect it to feel like a work from home job. YOU ARE GLUED TO YOUR DESK AT ALL TIMES. They will manage your time every second and you are on BACK TO BACK CALLS FOR 8 hours. And they will get on you for calling out. But the only reason why you call out bc your PTO days get denied every time for over a year. LIFE HAPPENS, THINGS HAPPEN, if I have over 40 hours banked of PTO VAC FLEX time why can’t I use it???? THERE IS NO ROOM FOR WORK LIFE BALANCE. Oh and the health benefits suck!!! Kaiser is the Walmart of all healthcare plans. I would rather pay out of pocket seeing a provider outside of network then ever dealing with a Kaiser MD. Kaiser doctors follow a script and cannot practice on their own all they do is offer telephone appts and never help you address your concerns. Stick to PPO or functional medicine. This is a miserable job working for miserable people who have to deal with miserable people on a daily basis. Don’t think just bc this department is unionized it will be any different Union representatives DO NOT have your back AT ALL. They are the most useless people there.I would rather go broke finding another job then stay here any longer. I’ve been here for almost a year and when I hear some employees she worked here for more than one, 5, or even over 10 years I’m like how the hell do u do it???

job_title: APPOINTMENT CLERK in Anaheim, CA
pros: the pay is competitive and you are part of a union. benefits are good and you will be working for a well known organization.
cons: As an appointment clerk, you will be taking back to back calls with little to no time in between calls or take a breath. There are hardly ever any appointments available to schedule which causes members to be frustrated and take it out on you. Hard to empathize with members because your calls will be consistently monitored, anything wrong that comes out of your mouth will be used against you. You are expected to keep calls under a certain time, any personal time used is to be kept to a minimum and they will track you over time, essentially what they are looking for are robots. Team managers will try to make you think it is a positive place to work at and throw in a few words of encouragement here and there, but don’t help when you need it and when you do find a way of reaching them they give you the run around on things or attitude. They are typically chit chatting, eating, away from their desks at another TM’s desk gossiping. You have almost no chance of getting a better schedule as there are employees who have been with the organization for many years and still stuck with a schedule that takes up almost your whole day. The organization supposedly values “speak up culture”, but the moment that an employee speaks up about something, they are shut down and targeted. Most team supervisors have no experience within the organization, most do not hold any degrees, and are extremely unprofessional, but it makes sense as it is just a call center environment. When hired ,employees are told that they like to hire and promote within which is false. An outsider has the same luck as someone who already works within the organization. Another thing to keep in mind is that calls are not distributed equally. If you are good at the job, you will be working 2-3x harder than others and not getting compensated. DO NOT BE FOOLED BY THEIR SLOGAN .

job_title: RN Case Manager in Vallejo, CA
pros: Kaiser is often a leader in interventions. They do lots of research, and have a store of data on many things they innovate. They have centers of excellence, that provide geographic locations where certain specialty services are provided. Kaiser is able to provide good service to many people of different income levels. The integration of the electronic medical record is very good. Kaiser offers medical financial assistance to some who can not afford their share of cost, but do not qualify for Medicaid.
cons: Although Kaiser is a leader in innovations, and an early adapter, they are also slow to adapt in some areas. Often the catalyst for them to adapt will come from a law, or from union pressure. An example is nurse staffing. In California the staffing ratios for nurses (RNs) are 5 patients to 1 nurse on an acute hospital floor. However, RNs working in case management have no cap on patient load. The case managers at Kaiser are under a lot of stress, and they are spread quite thin. It seems the managers take advantage of the fact that there is no ratio. They also would likely work to prevent a ratio for case managers.

review_title: KP looks good from the outside looking in...but it isn't Colorado KP
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Denver, CO
pros:
Pay is the absolute best in the market for staff nurses in Colorado
Health insurance is paid at 100% and is a great plan
Union job protection
cons:
If you don't have seniority you don't mean a thing. At Kaiser, a nurse is a nurse is a nurse. Years of experience do not matter, a strong work ethic does not matter, and the union is seniority-based only. You may have the skills to perform a position you want but if the senior wants it they get it. 
The Union is not a nursing union but a grocery store union

The company is constantly going through reorganizations so a nurse may find themselves in a wonderful clinic only to find out her role will be eliminated. Your job may be protected but once you are re-deployed you don't really know where you will go.

You never have the supplies to complete your tasks

Management is below par many with no clinical background

No work life balance

I also liked they matched my 401K (10% I think) and I got a pension (which I cannot cash out until I complete 5 years). Not sure there were any other pros besides (some) of the people I worked with. You quickly become grateful for the people who make work bearable and make your day easier instead of more difficult.
cons: There is no work life balance. Your work becomes your family (a hate-love relationship with some people). Too many people made the job more difficult by either being incompetent, rude, or both. job_title: Member Service Representative in Sacramento, CA
pros: Kaiser pays above average for nearly every position. The benefits are great, I cover my entire family with no issue. I pay very few copays for services and prescriptions. We also get an incremental raise annually with an annual bonus in the spring.
cons: There is not much room for individualism or advancement. They will act like your department is a "family" and expressing ideas is encouraged, but that is for show. KP is designed so that you shut up and do your job for 20+ years in the same department until you are retirement eligible, then you go. If you are looking to express yourself creatively or have highly fulfilling work, this place is not for you. If you don't mind feeling invisible and living the boring, water cooler talk cubicle life for solid pay and benefits then KP is the place for you. There have also been a LOT of changes post-covid, so I worry that the sense of security that KP used to offer is diminishing unless you are clinical staff.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician Outpatient in Fresno, CA
pros: The pay at Kaiser is the highest in the medical field that I know of. You have access to see how much people get paid based their position, the union they're in, and how many years they have been at Kaiser. It is union, except for any management/supervisor positions, so after your 3 month probation period it's almost impossible to get fired. The benefits are great, they are taken out of your union dues each pay period.
cons: It is union so everything is based on seniority , your hire date. Even if you work your butt off, you don't get higher pay or better shifts. It can take forever to get benefited. I am still on-call after 5 years! I can technically work 40 hours a week and still not have a benefited position. This is mainly due to the fact there was a lot of people hired in my department at the same time, therefore our hire date goes by the time we applied, since we all got hired on the same day. I am one of the last people not to have a position, but the pay is worth the wait. Again Kaiser is union, so coworkers can be lazy....I think they forgot just how easy they have it and how much they get paid. Management can't really do anything to discipline , or won't do anything since our union is so strong.

pros:
Amazing people to work with. The best Social Work Team I have ever worked with and you really fall in love with the company and what your role is. I loved my job but I resigned because I became a target/radar for my supervisors. I would have dedicated my life career to Kaiser, and I worked my butt off to get there. I finally had my dream job, two weeks into working their things changed. 
Let me just say that nit picking and never giving any positive redirection just negative feedback will break someones spirit. Educate yourselves its your key to a good job!!
cons: You will only get hired if you know someone and if you have years experiance. There is no room to start with kasier and to be trained as you grow in your profession. Poor communication and negative feedback is given. Director goes by the manager says about you so if your not liked by the office manager your position will not pass probation. If you have adhd and struggle with any learning disabilities do not even apply!! I resigned and left gracefully but I also was bullied by the director who has a record of bullying her employees!! And she's untouchable because her partner is the CEO of my region. Any formal complaint would disappear or get" swept under the rug" And why make eniemies that could possiably hurt me somewhere down the road.

job_title: Management Consultant in Oakland, CA
pros:
- Opportunity for incredibly positive and far reaching impact to patients, providers, and overall health systems. The work really matters. As an internal consultant, you often get to see the fruits of your labor through to implementation. 
- A great place to be involved with relevant issues hitting the healthcare industry. Kaiser is also ahead of the curve in a lot of healthcare matters, which is awesome. 
- The people in the department are so smart and driven. It’s a great environment to be in for learning and development. There is a collegiate and supportive culture from peers. 
- PTO and health benefits are extremely competitive, and probably even better than tech companies in the Bay Area. (However, they have the upper hand in way more free perks!) 
- The department gets to be at the center of most (if not all) strategic projects happening at KP, which range from advocating for policy to clinical delivery enhancements and patient engagement. It's very rewarding to be at the crux of change at such a large org. 
- Good mix of strategy x operations x management consulting in healthcare 
- Strong opportunities for KP senior leadership exposure & relationship building 
- Overall, a really good place to be if you can get past tone deaf senior leadership and know how to consistently advocate for yourself for growth opportunities. There has been change in senior leadership recently. It's still too early to tell, but hopefully this will mean a positive outlook for the future.

(One thing to note, for some reason Glassdoor is indicating I do not approve of the CEO, but I am actually just neutral)
cons:
- Upper management puts the organization over the people, which is not good for long-term employee retention.
- There needs to be a better way to match consultants with projects that are truly interesting to them - especially after being at the company for more than a year. Management, please take inputs and actually act on them, rather than hastily assigning consultants to projects in a reactive way. When working on 2-4 projects at a time, consultants should be on at least ONE project that they are truly passionate about, or that at least helps them build/flex skills they are targeting. 
- Did not feel there was significant thought put towards staff safety or comfort during the pandemic; even when every other company was working from home, it seemed like senior leadership had an expectation that people shouldn’t be too far from the office, when the norm should have been the opposite. We weren't even able to leave the state to be with families due to HR policy. Hopefully this changes as remote work continues to be ironed out... 
- There is just a divide between antiquated ideas of business practice from leadership and a dynamic, innovative culture from the consulting staff.

review_title: Great Place to Work Depending on Organization and Department
job_title: Business Process Consultant in Oakland, CA
pros: I worked at KP for 8 years both in IT as an IT Consultant/Business Analyst and as a Business Process Consultant for Health Plan. It's a large, complex organization. Due to its size and complexity most employees are relatively secure in their positions. Also, depending on the department, some of the work can be highly engaging and rewarding. Prior to my leaving for another organization KP had begun embracing the work from home model even before the pandemic began, and will most likely continue down this path once the pandemic ends. Work-life balance can be good or bad depending on the department - I'd say Program Offices lacked in this regard. Great PTO, pension and retirement benefits.
cons: Some departments/stakeholders are highly political. Some departments carry "dead weight" where they've had employees on the payroll that don't perform to reasonable standards. You'll see many titles labeled as "consultant", when in reality the role may be doing program or project management work where anywhere else would demand a higher salary. Personally, I left simply because I'd reached a cap in how far I could be promoted or find a higher paying position - I think they could do a better job in promoting or offering advancement to staff, as by keeping the "dead-weight" mixed with high performers they encourage a culture of non-commitment from employees.

job_title: Psychiatrist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits are second to none, particularly healthcare benefits which include unlimited outpatient visits, ER visits, and hospitalization for yourself and dependents as well as retirement benefits which include a 401k, Keogh, and pension. The people are friendly and overall the culture is very positive and supportive.
cons: There is no cap on patient case loads and the demand is HIGH. You will continue to take new patients daily even if you do not have any follow-up availability for months out and it is very difficult to see a patient more frequently than once every 3 months at the most which brings up frustration for patients and physicians alike. There is not a lot of vacation time offered and it must be requested a minimum of 5 months in advance. Also, every hour of your schedule is scrupulously monitored. For example, if you generally work a 10-hour day and are off on Thanksgiving, 2 hours will be removed from your vacation time because holidays are only provided for up to 8 hours.
